text: we're at a moment of real flux in this
um because when I wrote the book The
abstinence teacher I wrote it um as a
kind of reaction to the 2004 election
and um to that sense I had at that point
that there's just this yawning cultural
divide between the blue States and the
red states and that we're living in two
entirely separate realities and what I
wanted to do is try and get those two
realities into one town so create a kind
of microcosm of the culture War by the
time the book came out in
2007 I don't think I was alone in
feeling like the culture War had sort of
died down um there had been that
Watershed election in 2006 where the
Democrats had kind of taken over the
house you know bush had gotten so mired
in the debacle of Iraq that uh his
social agenda kind of uh fell part
there'd also been a series of scandals
involving you know the Reverend Ted
Haggard Mark Foley all the sort of uh
guardians of morality on the right had
once again exposed themselves as uh you
know Hypocrites to some degree or
other but by the time and then a year
went by McCain is running he's running
as the one Republican who didn't seem to
have a very strong cultural and social
social conservative agenda but then he
picked Sarah Palin to be his running
mate and you could just see see that
that sort of latent culture War just
flared back up it was just right in
front of us and there were all these
sort of angry social conservatives who
just have been deeply frustrated because
uh they'd been marginalized in the
Republican primaries um but in that
period between you know around 2007
there was this real sense that the
monolithic um voice of the Evangelical
right had started to break down you know
it as if like these liberal Christians
who' been hiding for years just suddenly
came out and said hey wait a minute it
you know Jesus wasn't just talking about
sexual morality Jesus was talking about
poverty Jesus was talking about being
stewards of the earth you know and there
was a and I I think that's still going
on I think I think that um the
Evangelical right doesn't have the clap
that it used to have but we'd be wrong
to think that it just went away it's
there um but it's not going to
dominate um the Republican party for one
the way it did in the sort of Carl Ro
George Bush manner um and and one thing
that happened as a result of writing
this book um was I
heard uh I I got uh emails from from a
lot of Christians but in a way it's not
surprising there were liberal Christians
um who I think were sympathetic
to uh the way that I wrote about the
character Tim who is a guy who has in a
sense been saved by religion but is
struggling to
um really figure out
how he can live his
life um in a Christian way it's it's not
you know he it's it's hard and it's a
struggle and certain things make sense
to him and certain things don't I mean
he's he's a kind of searching Christian
figure and and um I didn't get a whole
lot of flack from the far right because
I just don't think they read novels and
they I don't think they read novels like
this for sure but I did get a lot of um
really interesting responses from
Liberal Christians who um I think felt
like like a lot of the book rang true
uh to people that they'd known and
struggles that they'd had with um you
know trying to live live a Christian
life but uh
also you know have a kind of more um
flexible or tolerant um set of moral
standards particularly around sexual
issues
